original_data.question: A study is conducted to determine the most effective ways to prevent transmission of various infective agents. One of the agents studied is a picornavirus that preferentially infects hepatocytes. The investigator determines that inactivating this virus can prevent its spread. Which of the following disinfectants is most likely to inactivate this virus?

model_response:
{'A': 'Chlorhexidine', 'B': 'Sodium hypochlorite', 'C': 'Sulfuric acid', 'D': 'Ethyl alcohol'}[?] Chlorhexidine is effective against a wide range of viruses including hepatitis A, hepatitis B, and enteroviruses. Sodium hypochlorite is also effective against hepatitis A, B, and enteroviruses, as well as against HIV. Sulfuric acid has no effect on viruses. Ethyl alcohol is effective against some enveloped viruses, such as HIV and hepatitis B, but not against picornaviruses. Glycerol is used to preserve samples of hepatitis B virus. Isopropyl alcohol is used to preserve samples of enteroviruses.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A work that reports on the results of a research study to evaluate interventions or exposures on biomedical or health-related outcomes. The two main types of clinical studies are interventional studies (clinical trials) and observational studies. While most clinical studies concern humans, this publication type may be used for clinical veterinary articles meeting the requisites for humans.
The capacity to bring about a desired effect.
Used with diseases for studies of the modes of transmission.
Any organism, such as a virus, parasite, or bacterium, that is capable of invading body tissues and multiplying.
Articles of food which are derived by a process of manufacture from any portion of carcasses of any animal used for food (e.g., head cheese, sausage, scrapple).

A family of small RNA viruses comprising some important pathogens of humans and animals. Transmission usually occurs mechanically. There are nine genera: APHTHOVIRUS; CARDIOVIRUS; ENTEROVIRUS; ERBOVIRUS; HEPATOVIRUS; KOBUVIRUS; PARECHOVIRUS; RHINOVIRUS; and TESCHOVIRUS.
The main structural component of the LIVER. They are specialized EPITHELIAL CELLS that are organized into interconnected plates called lobules.
To cause something to start or to stimulate activity.
Minute infectious agents whose genomes are composed of DNA or RNA, but not both. They are characterized by a lack of independent metabolism and the inability to replicate outside living host cells.
The act of extending over a wider scope or expanse of space or time.

Substances used on inanimate objects that destroy harmful microorganisms or inhibit their activity. Disinfectants are classed as complete, destroying SPORES as well as vegetative forms of microorganisms, or incomplete, destroying only vegetative forms of the organisms. They are distinguished from ANTISEPTICS, which are local anti-infective agents used on humans and other animals. (From Hawley's Condensed Chemical Dictionary, 11th ed)
To cause the elimination of an activity.
Minute infectious agents whose genomes are composed of DNA or RNA, but not both. They are characterized by a lack of independent metabolism and the inability to replicate outside living host cells.
